Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a child wearing a festival wreath headdress (Eros or Harpocrates?) over hair worn as loose curls tumbling down his neck. He is holding a shield and a short sword. The shield is of Gaulish type, with a central spine. He wears a cloak fastened at the right shoulder and draped over his left side. Hollow, from two-piece mould. Traces of white coating. Red-brown Nile silt with abundant mica and white inclusions. The top of the headdress is broken, the nose is chipped.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
A cleruch in the same style, carying a gallic shield is known from Naukratis (British Museum GR1888,0601.97), dated to the 3rd century BC. This example follows Tanagra types representing boys.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.429) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4564 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
